title: psc-vignette
text: psc.R package implements methods applying Personalised Synthetic Controls, allows patients receiving experimental treatment compared model predicts reponse control. form causal inference differes approaches Causal inference, theory least, estimated patient level - opposed estimating average effects population causal estimand obtained Average Treatment Effect Treated (ATT) differs Average Treatment Effect (ATE) obtained settings addresses question whether treatments effective population patients treated. estimand targets efficacy effectivness. basic form, method creates likelihood compare cohort data parametric model. See (X) disucssion ’s use causal inference tool. use package, two basic peices information required, dataset model can compared. vignette, detail psc.r package constructed give examples ’s application practice.

title: psc-vignette
text: pscfit function compares dataset (‘DC’) parametric model. done selecting likelihood identified type CFM supplied. present, two types model supported, flexible parmaeteric survival model type ‘flexsurvreg’ geleneralised linear model type ‘glm’. CFM type ‘flexsurvreg’ likeihood supplied form: L(D∣Λ,Γi)=∏=1nf(ti∣Λ,Γi)ciS(ti∣Γ,Λi)(1−ci)L(D∣\Lambda,\Gamma_i)=\prod_{=1}^{n} f(t_i∣\Lambda,\Gamma_i)^{c_i}  S(t_i∣\Gamma,\Lambda_i)^{(1−c_i)} Γ\Gamma defines cumulative baseline hazard function, Λ\Lambda linear predictor tt cc event time indicator variables. CFM type ‘glm’ likelihood supplied form: L(x∣Γi)=∏=1nb(x∣Γi)exp{Γit(x)−c(Γi)}L(x∣\Gamma_i) = \prod_{=1}^{n} b (x∣ \Gamma_i )\exp\{\Gamma_i t(x)− c(\Gamma_i)\} b(.)b(.), t(.)t(.) c(.)c(.) represent functions exponential family. cases, Γ\Gamma defiend : Γi=γxi+β \Gamma_i = \gamma x_i+\beta γ\gamma model coefficients supplied CFM β\beta parameter set measure difference CFM DC. Estimation performed using Bayesian MCMC procedure. Prior distributions Γ\Gamma (& Λ\Lambda) derived directly model coefficients (mean variance covariance matrix) CFM. bespoke MCMC routine performed estimate β\beta. Please see ‘?mcmc’ detials. standard example DC contains information single treatment, trt need specified. comparisons CFM multiple treatments require, covariate treamtne allocations must specified sperately (using ‘trt’ option).

title: psc-vignette
text: main function using applying Personal Synthetic Controls pscfit() function two inputs, Counter-Factual Model (CFM) data cohort (DC). arguments include nsim sets number MCMC iterations (defaults 5000) ‘id’ user wishes restrict estimation sub-set (individual) within DC ‘trt’ used initial identifier mulitple treatment comparisons made (please see Mulitple Treatment Comparison )

title: psc-vignette
text: output “pscfit()” function object class ‘psc’. class contains following attributes definition calss model supplied ‘cleaned’ dataset including extracted components CFM cleaned DC included procedure object defingin class model (therefore procedure applied - see ) matrix containing draws posterior distributions

title: psc-vignette
text: basic post estimation functions developed work psc object, namely “print()”, “coef()”, “summary()” “plot()”. first three provided basic summaries efficacy parameter obtained posterior distribution.

title: psc-vignette
text: psc.r package includes example dataset “e4_data” derived patients ith pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) received experimental treatment, case GemCap. Aside also provide Counter Factual Model (CFM) patients setting (named ‘gemCFM’) receive therapy called ‘Gem’. aim produce ‘GemCap Vs Gem’ comparison. start loading package obtianing data model analysis. #{r} #library(parallel) #library(posterior) #library(ggplot2) #library(survminer) #library(ggpubr) #library(survival) # Starting model, can inspect model terms included counter factual model using Included list prognostic covariates: Lymph Nodes: patient lymph node status; negative (n=1) positive (n=2) lymph nodes Diff_Status: tumour grade; 1,2 3 PostOpCA199: log transformed ca19.9 Similarly can observe outcome terms. gemCFM object survival model includes terms named “time” “cen”. NB pscfit function search terms important outcomes included data cohort (DC) labelled way. Importantly covariates included DC must names match . Prior comparing DC CFM advisable get good understanding data included CFM. Within CFM object series plots visualise covariate values can extracted using ‘plotCFM’ function  give esamples ‘pscfit()’ function can used comapre data models survival outcomes (‘flexsurvreg’ model). Examples perform analyses using GLM model objects available github repo https://github.com/richJJackson/psc
code: remove.packages("psc") #> Removing package from '/home/runner/work/_temp/Library' #> (as 'lib' is unspecified) #rm(list=ls()) library(devtools) #> Loading required package: usethis install_github("richjjackson/psc") #> Using github PAT from envvar GITHUB_PAT. Use `gitcreds::gitcreds_set()` and unset GITHUB_PAT in .Renviron (or elsewhere) if you want to use the more secure git credential store instead. #> Downloading GitHub repo richjjackson/psc@HEAD #> digest (0.6.37 -> 0.6.38) [CRAN] #> lsoda  (NA     -> 1.2   ) [CRAN] #> rstpm2 (1.7.0  -> 1.7.1 ) [CRAN] #> Installing 3 packages: digest, lsoda, rstpm2 #> Installing packages into '/home/runner/work/_temp/Library' #> (as 'lib' is unspecified) #> ── R CMD build ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> * checking for file ‘/tmp/Rtmpg7vJtB/remotes20bdc6fb51b/richJJackson-psc-8e978b3/DESCRIPTION’ ... OK #> * preparing ‘psc’: #> * checking DESCRIPTION meta-information ... OK #> * checking for LF line-endings in source and make files and shell scripts #> * checking for empty or unneeded directories #> * building ‘psc_2.0.0.tar.gz’ #> Installing package into '/home/runner/work/_temp/Library' #> (as 'lib' is unspecified) library(psc) #> Loading required package: survival #> Loading required package: ggplot2 e4_data <- psc::e4_data gemCFM <- psc::gemCFM gemCFM$terms #> [1] "LymphN"      "ResecM"      "Diff_Status" "PostOpCA199" "(weights)" gemCFM$out.nm #> [1] "time" "cen" plotCFM(gemCFM)

title: psc-vignette
text: example survival outcome model must supplied contructed ont basis flexible parametric splines. contructed using “flexsurvreg” function within “flexsurv” package. example included within ‘psc.r’ package names ‘surv.mod’ loaded using ’data()” function: ‘gemCFM’ object class pscCFM means contains structures required analysis stripped model object patient level data. Please note psc package can used providing standard ‘glm’ ‘flexsurvreg’ models. procedures convert model ‘pscCFM’ object using pscCFM() function. example ‘gemCFM’ model constructed 5 internal knots hence 7 parameters describe baseline cumulative hazard function: also prognostic covariates match prognostic covariates data cohort…. process comparing DC CFM occures across 4 steps: Step 1: Combine/Compare DC CFM using pscData() function Step 2: Obtain initial values estimation procedue using init() Step 3: Run MCMC estimation procedure Step 4: Collate summarise results steps update ‘pscOb’ object resutls returned user. process wrapped single ‘pscfit()’ function/ NB. warning supplied just note data removed form DC prior analysis due missing data. can view attributes psc object created. includes details components including CFM, DC, likelihood applied, starting values posterior distribuion worth noting part ‘pscData()’ function ensures DC CFM compatible - ‘datavis’ object updated. now produce useful figure allow evaulation comparable data CFM DC using ‘plotCFM()’ function  make use ‘posterior’ package summarise posterior distributions (saved within ‘draws’ object). ‘print()’ ‘coef()’ show although ‘summary()’ function provides mode information: includes information underlying CFM well expected meand response patients DC along 95% CI (obtianed using bootstrapping). summary MCMC fit supplied along overall summary posterior distribution. Lastly visualise original model fit data, plot function included
code: gemCFM$haz_co #>      gamma0      gamma1      gamma2      gamma3      gamma4      gamma5  #> -11.3808020   3.8359818   1.2911623  -1.3176560   1.1190182  -0.8876277  #>      gamma6  #>   0.3372484 gemCFM$cov_co #>      LymphN1      ResecM1 Diff_Status1 Diff_Status2  PostOpCA199  #>    0.4876152    0.1805322   -0.4160534   -0.5897823    0.2671471 attributes(surv.psc) #> $names #>  [1] "mod_class" "terms"     "out.nm"    "cov_class" "cov_lev"   "co"        #>  [7] "cov_co"    "sig"       "haz_co"    "k"         "kn"        "lam"       #> [13] "formula"   "datasumm"  "datavis"   "DC"        "lik"       "start.mu"  #> [19] "start.sd"  "cfmPost"   "target"    "betaPrior" "ncores"    "draws"     #> [25] "postFit"   "postEst"   #>  #> $class #> [1] "psc" plotCFM(surv.psc) summary(surv.psc) #> Counterfactual Model (CFM):  #> A model of class 'flexsurvreg'  #>  Fit with 5 internal knots #>  #> CFM Formula:  #> Surv(time, cen) ~ LymphN + ResecM + Diff_Status + PostOpCA199 #> <environment: 0x564544085670> #>  #> CFM Summary:  #> Expected response for the outcome under the CFM: #>     S     lo     hi   #> 30.30  25.51  35.79   #>  #> Observed outcome from the Data Cohort: #>          [,1]  #> median   26.33 #> 0.95LCL  22.85 #> 0.95UCL  31.03 #>  #> MCMC Fit:  #> Posterior Distribution obtaine with fit summary: #>       variable     rhat         ess_bulk     ess_tail     mcse_mean   #> [1,]  beta_1       1.00219      982.9588     969.0546     0.002770336 #>  #> Summary:  #> Posterior Distribution for beta:Call: #>  CFM model + beta #>  #> Coefficients: #>            variable       mean           sd             median        #> posterior  beta_1         -0.003323009   0.08782652     -0.0003282747 #>            q5             q95           #> posterior  -0.1532584     0.130359 plot(surv.psc) #>            variable       mean           sd             median        #> posterior  beta_1         -0.003323009   0.08782652     -0.0003282747 #>            q5             q95           #> posterior  -0.1532584     0.130359 #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the ggpubr package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/kassambara/ggpubr/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call title: Personalised Synthetic Controls
text: basic example shows solve common problem: can use standard commands getting summary analysis… … see plot done  case, don’t forget commit push resulting figure files, display GitHub CRAN.
code: library(psc) #> Warning: replacing previous import 'posterior::var' by 'stats::var' when #> loading 'psc' #> Warning: replacing previous import 'posterior::sd' by 'stats::sd' when loading #> 'psc' #> Warning: replacing previous import 'posterior::mad' by 'stats::mad' when #> loading 'psc' library(survival) ## basic example code  ### Load model data("surv.mod")  ### Load Data data("data") #> Warning in data("data"): data set 'data' not found  ### Use 'pscfit' to compare surv.psc <- pscfit(surv.mod,data) #> Warning in pscData_match(CFM$cov_class, CFM$cov_lev, DCcov): vi specified as a character in the model, consider respecifying #>                 as a factor to ensure categories match between CFM and DC #> Warning in pscData_match(CFM$cov_class, CFM$cov_lev, DCcov): allmets specified as a character in the model, consider respecifying #>                 as a factor to ensure categories match between CFM and DC summary(surv.psc) #> Counterfactual Model (CFM):  #> A model of class 'flexsurvreg'  #>  Fit with 3 internal knots #>  #> CFM Formula:  #> Surv(time, cen) ~ vi/age60 + ecog + allmets + logafp + alb +  #>     logcreat + logast + aet #> <environment: 0x11b23ef28> #>  #> CFM Summary:  #> Expected response for the outcome under the CFM: #>      S      lo      hi   #>  9.694   9.094  10.653   #>  #> Observed outcome from the Data Cohort: #>          [,1]  #> median   6.366 #> 0.95LCL  5.436 #> 0.95UCL  9.094 #>  #> MCMC Fit:  #> Posterior Distribution obtaine with fit summary: #>       variable    rhat        ess_bulk    ess_tail    mcse_mean  #> [1,]  beta_1      1.000707    4222.245    3977.807    0.00151382 #>  #> Summary:  #> Posterior Distribution for beta:Call: #>  CFM model + beta #>  #> Coefficients: #>            variable    mean        sd title: Function for performing Bayesian MCMC estimation procedures in 'pscfit' — pscEst
text: matrix containing draws form posterior distribution

title: Function for performing Bayesian MCMC estimation procedures in 'pscfit' — pscEst
text: Define set model parameters \(B\) contain \(\Gamma\) summarize parameters CFM. Prior distributions defined B using multivariate normal distribution \(\pi (B) \sim MVN(\mu ,\Sigma)\) \(\mu|\) vector coefficient estimates validated model \(\Sigma\) variance-covariance matrix. information taken directly outputs parametric model elicitation required. prior distirbution efficacy parameter (\(\pi{(\beta)}\)) set uniformative \(N(0,1000)\). Ultimately aim estimate posterior distribution \(\beta\) conditional distribution B observed data.  full form posterior distribution given $$P(\beta \vert B,D) \propto L(D \vert B,\beta) \pi(B) \pi(\beta)$$ Please see 'pscfit' details liklihood formation. iteration MCMC procedure, following algorithm performed Set indicator s=1, define initial state based prior hyperparameters \(\pi(B)\)  \(\pi(\beta)\) \(b_s = \mu \tau_s=0\) Update \(s = s+1\) draw model parameters \(b_s\) \(\pi(B)\) draw proposal estimate \(\beta\) target distribution Estimate \(\Gamma_(,S)=\nu^T x_i\) \(\nu\) subset parameters \(b_s\)  relate model covariates define 2 new likelihood functions    \(\Theta_(s,1)=L(D \vert B=b_s,\beta=\tau_(s-1) )\) & \(\Theta_(s,2)= L(D \vert B=b_s,\beta=\tau_s)\) Draw single value \(\psi\) Uniform (0,1) distribution estimate condition \(\omega=  \Theta_(s,1)/\Theta_(s,2)\). \(\omega > \psi\) accept \(\tau_s\) belonging posterior distribution \(P(\beta \vert B,D)\) otherwise retain \(\tau_(s-1)\) Repeat steps 2 – 4 required number iterations result algorithm posterior distribution log hazard ratio, \(\beta\), captures variability B defined priors \(\pi{(\beta)}\).  @examples e4_data <- psc::e4_data gemCFM <- psc::gemCFM pscOb <- pscData(gemCFM,e4_data) pscOb <- init(pscOb) pscOb <- pscEst(pscOb,nsim=1500,nchain=1) importFrom survival Surv survfit

what: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
title: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
text: Function allows comparison data cohort parametric Counter Factual Model (CFM). function allows models type 'flexsurvreg' 'glm' supplied. function performs calculating linear predictor combination CFM dataset supplied selects likelihood based type model specified.  Likelihood estimated using Baysian MCMC procedure wherebey parameters CFM acts informative priors.

title: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
code: pscfit(   CFM,   DC,   nsim = 2000,   id = NULL,   trt = NULL,   nchain = 2,   thin = 2,   burn = 500 )

title: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
text: CFM R model object class 'glm' 'flexsurvspline' DC dataset including columns match covariates model nsim number simulations MCMC routine id Numeric vector stating patient(s) dataset included analysis. Defaults patients trt optional vector denoting treatment allocations multiple treatment comparisons.  Defaults NULL. nchain Number chains used posterior MCMC estimation.  Defaults nchain=3. thin Thin applied posterior draws.  Defaults thin=2. burn Number posterior samples use burn-.  Defaults burn=500

title: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
text: object class 'psc' attributes model.type, cleaned Dataset   posterior distribution fitted model Attributes include 'cleaned' dataset including extracted components CFM  cleaned DC included procedure object defining class model (therefore procedure  applied - see ) matrix containing draws posterior distributions

title: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
text: Model currently supports estimation one treatment (using 'trt') option esitmation restricted sub-groups data cohort (using 'id' option. pscfit function compares dataset ('DC') parametric model.   done selecting likelihood identified type CFM supplied.   present, two types model supported, flexible parmaeteric survival model type 'flexsurvreg'   geleneralised linear model type 'glm'. CFM type 'flexsurvreg' likeihood supplied form: $$L(D \vert \Lambda, \Gamma_i) = \prod^{n}_{=1} f(t_i \vert  \Lambda, \Gamma_i)^{c_i}   S(t_i|\Lambda, \Gamma_i)^{(1-c_i)}$$ \(\Lambda\) defines cumulative baseline hazard function,   \(\Gamma\) linear predictor \(t\) \(c\)   event time indicator variables. CFM type 'glm' likelihood supplied form: $$L(x \vert \Gamma_i) = \prod^{n}_{=1} b(x \vert \Gamma_i) \exp{\{\Gamma_i^T t(x)    - c(\Gamma_i)\} } $$ \(b(.)\), \(t(.)\) \(c(.)\) represent functions   exponential family. cases, \(\Gamma\) defined : $$\Gamma = \gamma x + \beta$$ \(\gamma\) model coefficients supplied CFM \(\beta\)   parameter set measure difference CFM DC. Estimation performed using Bayesian MCMC procedure.  Prior distributions    \(\Gamma\) (& \(\Lambda\)) derived directly model    coefficients (mean variance covariance matrix) CFM. bespoke MCMC    routine performed estimate \(\beta\).  Please see '?mcmc' detials. standard example DC contains information single    treatment, trt need specified.  comparisons CFM    multiple treatments require, covariate treamtne allocations must    specified sperately (using 'trt' option).

title: Personalised Synthetic Controls model fit — pscfit
